Title: Inside Alyssa Thompson's move to Chelsea: Tearful goodbyes, late nights and customary pizza
Description:
Women's Soccer

By Charlotte Harpur, Melanie Anzidei and Tamerra Griffin

Twenty-one days ago, Alyssa Thompson scored a critical match-winner against the reigning National Women's Soccer League (NWSL) champions, the Orlando Pride, breaking an eight-match winless drought for Angel City FC. She powered the ball past Brazilian forward Marta with her left arm wrapped in a thick cast, making the feat all the more impressive.

Advertisement

It would prove to be the last on-field action of this current chapter with her hometown club, but the story was far from over.

Thompson's arm is still bound in a cast, but now she is wearing the colors of Chelsea Women's team after signing with the eight-time Women's Super League (WSL) title-holders last week.

Though Thompson is still waiting for final eligibility approval on her cast WSL Football rules state that player safety is the primary consideration, with any protective equipment deemed dangerous not permitted to wear. Non-soft casts are judged for their safety by the match official, who has the final call. However, Chelsea head coach Sonia Bompastor said in a press conference last week that she is hopeful Thompson will be able to play on Sunday against Aston Villa.

It's been a whirlwind past few weeks for the 20-year-old, which says a lot considering her high-profile roots.

The moment Thompson became Angel City's No. 1 pick in the NWSL draft in January 2023 was a wholesome picture.

Then 18 years old, she was sandwiched on a big couch between her two younger sisters, Gisele and Zoe, surrounded by their parents and dozens of friends and family. There was no real sense of mystery over her draft status, and yet Thompson took deep breaths as she awaited the sound of her name.

As soon as NWSL commissioner Jessica Berman read it, she broke into a wide grin and brought her hands to her face. Thompson had foregone Stanford for this, and now her fate was all but sealed with Angel City as the team entered its second season in Los Angeles.

It didn't take long for her sacrifices to pay off. In Thompson's first 11 minutes of regular-season soccer, she scored her team's only goal in a 2-1 loss to Gotham FC in March 2023.

But Thompson's departure from Angel City two years and eight months later was less pristine.

There were lengthy discussions in a clandestine suite inside BMO Stadium, where Angel City plays, that continued across the continent and ocean to England, Thompson's Instagram Story post of a text message screenshot with the reminder not to “let someone rob your happiness,” and tears that fell during a farewell to teammates before the deal was done.

Advertisement

The tense process was one Angel City and the NWSL would have wanted to prevent from happening altogether. It is another U.S. player now unavailable for promotion after a season without strikers Sophia Wilson and Mallory Swanson (both of whom are on maternity leave) and having only recently seen the return of Trinity Rodman.

“We are diligent and fair in our negotiations to ensure that we protect the rights of the league and our clubs and to maintain strong working relationships around the world,” an NWSL spokesperson told The Athletic.

Still, Thompson blazed her path from Los Angeles to London over the past few weeks as determined as she is when she has the ball at her feet.

Turning back is rarely an option for her.

Even as Chelsea navigated injuries to key players like centerback Kadeisha Buchanan, striker Sam Kerr, and centerback Naomi Girma, for whom the club had paid a then-record $1 million in transfer fees to bring over from the San Diego Wave in January, they still enjoyed an unbeaten season and a domestic treble last year.

Not only are those players back this season, but Chelsea continued padding its roster with the likes of Australian fullback Ellie Carpenter from OL Lyonnes and Swiss goalkeeper Livia Peng from Werder Bremen.

Still, compared to Arsenal's £1 million signing of 21-year-old Olivia Smith in July, Chelsea was quiet during the transfer window until the late push for Thompson. They were reluctant to splurge on another record signing, according to sources briefed on the negotiation, and who, like all in this piece, requested to remain anonymous to protect relationships.

But adding Thompson, for just over $1 million, boosts an already winning squad. On the field, she is one of the top wingers in the world, a position Chelsea has been looking to add depth to. Off it, she provides plenty of marketing upside.

Advertisement

Last Friday, Bompastor said during a press conference that the team decided early in the summer transfer window to bring a new winger into the squad. Thompson's versatility as a right-footed winger, who is comfortable playing down the left flank, appealed to Chelsea, but her profile is not a replacement for Lauren James or Mayra Ramirez, who are dealing with injuries. However, winger Guro Reiten's contract expires at the end of this season.

Chelsea had been monitoring Thompson for some time, but it seemed unlikely she would move given she had just signed a three-year contract extension with Angel City in January. Initially, a January transfer for Thompson after the NWSL season concluded seemed more likely, especially since Angel City occupied ninth place in the table, just outside of playoff contention.

Thompson's success in the NWSL and with the USWNT also comes with more attention from sponsors. Alyssa and Gisele were the first high schoolers to sign a name, image and likeness (NIL) deal with Nike and recently became the face of NYX Professional Makeup's “Make Them Look” campaign.

The sisters have been somewhat of a package deal since Gisele signed with Angel City in December 2023, and they excelled at their Los Angeles club. Their rapid success led to Angel City extending both players' contracts in January. And in May, they connected for the first sister-to-sister goal in NWSL history. The sisters, born just 13 months apart, are extremely close and lived together in Los Angeles.

Angel City pushed to keep the younger Thompson stateside, too, offering the 19-year-old a contract extension through 2029, which they announced the same day Alyssa was presented at Chelsea. Alyssa's move gives the sisters an opportunity to step into their own spotlights.

When Thompson's camp realized Chelsea were serious about making a deal and willing to spend seven figures for the forward, talks sped up, according to sources. Thompson leaned on her family for support and even tapped her U.S. national team head coach Emma Hayes for guidance on Chelsea before making a final decision.

“Emma always talks about her experiences at Chelsea in the national team, and just, like, how much she loved it,” Thompson said in an interview with the club. “But when I talked to Emma about coming here, she really wanted to make sure this was the right decision for me. She really supports her players. She was asking me the right questions to really make me understand if I truly wanted to be here or not.”

Advertisement

Thompson added that engaging with Hayes' questions “helped me know in my heart that I actually did want to come here, even though there would be difficult things that I might face.”

Chelsea's winning record also made for a stark reality check between Angel City and Chelsea as the 2027 World Cup looms. Angel City have played in one NWSL playoff game so far, a 1-0 quarterfinal loss against Seattle Reign in 2023, in which Thompson subbed on during the second half. Since Thompson was not named in the USWNT's 2024 Concacaf W Gold Cup roster or the 2024 Summer Olympics, she has very little experience playing knockout stage football for club or country.

The Guardian first reported Chelsea's interest in Thompson on Thursday, Aug. 28. By Monday, three days before the transfer deadline, Thompson's team was at BMO pushing to get the deal through, as Angel City played Bay FC at home. Time was already thinning, and the fact that the talks took place over Labor Day weekend further slowed negotiations, according to sources.

Thompson was absent from the line-up on an excused absence.

The league told The Athletic its “player affairs team works around the clock to ensure we meet US and international deadlines.”

On Tuesday, Thompson shared a message on Instagram, a screenshot of a text advising the recipient not to “let someone rob your happiness.” However, she would soon be on her way to London, where she arrived Thursday morning around 10 a.m. Thompson's agent almost missed his flight from the United States because the permission to fly was given so late; however, he made it.



Angel City did what it could to keep Alyssa, going as far as offering the highest salary the club could manage, according to a source, but it wasn't enough to sway her final decision.

Before she finally left for London on Wednesday night, still waiting to finalize a deal, Thompson left each of her teammates a handwritten note saying goodbye.

Advertisement

The deal went down to the wire. FaceTime calls stretched across time zones as those involved were up until midnight and 1 a.m. local times. On Thursday, with the deadline nearing, the team filmed promotional material at Cobham, Chelsea's training facility, before the deal was finalized, according to sources. Both Angel City and Chelsea declined to comment on the nature of the talks.

Disputes over contractual language weren't resolved until 8 or 9 p.m., mere hours ahead of the 11 p.m. deadline. In the room were Chelsea's head of women's football, Paul Green, and head of player recruitment TJ O'Leary, Thompson's father, uncle and youth coach, as well as her agents from A&V Sports and their commercial team.

As is customary at Chelsea on deadline day, Domino's pizza was ordered, as negotiations continued late into the night.

Thompson and her agent finally signed the transfer papers and confirmed the five-year deal just 30 minutes before the transfer window closed.

 

 

A post shared by Takumi Jeannin (@takumi.jeannin)



The Athletic reported an initial deal valued Thompson's transfer at just under $1.3 million, with other sources later saying the figure is closer to $1.45 million. If all of the contract's add-ons are met, depending on Thompson's and Chelsea's performances over the next five seasons, it will likely raise that total. Angel City announced the move as an NWSL record for an outgoing transfer, surpassing Girma's $1 million.

The heavy investment by Chelsea with their five-year, fully-guaranteed contract is a statement of commitment that the club envisions Thompson as part of their long-term plan.

However, the move is not necessarily a goodbye to Los Angeles, more of a see-you-later.

After all, LA is Thompson's home; it is where her family is, though they plan to make staggered visits to London. With Chelsea, Thompson chose to wear the No. 12 jersey, a quiet nod to the No. 21 she wore with Angel City.

As if scripted by the writers in her hometown of Hollywood, Thompson's Chelsea move means she is returning to the city where she first stepped into the spotlight as a 17-year-old making her national team debut.

Advertisement

On October 7, 2022, the U.S. visited England for a friendly against the recently-crowned European champions England at Wembley Stadium. Ninety thousand fans packed the house for a high-octane meeting between two of the best in the world — and in the 83rd minute, as the U.S. trailed the Lionesses 2-1, Thompson came in as a substitute for Megan Rapinoe. She was and remains the first teenager in USWNT history to make such a high-profile debut.

Even then, her contemplative nature was evident — but equally apparent were the things about which she was certain.

“Since I started playing soccer, this is all I wanted to do,” Thompson, speaking to U.S. Soccer after the game, said. “I'm kind of speechless. Like, it's kind of hitting me now that I just played.”

(Top photo: Aaron M. Sprecher / Getty Images; design: Eamonn Dalton)

Title: SSFC Spotlight: Lilly Reale shows grit in debut NWSL season
Description:
The rookie made her USWNT debut over the summer.

The United States Women's National Team has been going through what ESPN termed “the most drastic overhaul in the 40-year history” of the program, with Emma Hayes searching for her ideal group. The fullback position remains “anyone's guess,” as the manager has given an opportunity for several players to stake a claim. Lilly Reale is one of the newer additions to the pool, having picked up two starts at the most recent camp. The 22-year-old Gotham FC defender is building a strong rookie season after a sterling collegiate career.

Born in Boston, Massachusetts, Reale competed with South Shore Select and was teammates with Ally Sentnor. At the scholastic level, she played for Hingham High School and amassed 36 goals in her first two seasons before moving to defender while also competing for the basketball team. Her various honors included All-League, All-State, All-Region, and All-American, boosted by regular experience with the national team program.

After initially committing to Boston College, Reale matriculated to the University of California, Los Angeles and opened her collegiate career by starting in 19 matches, being named All-Pac-12 First-Team and Freshman Best XI and All-Freshman First Team by Top Drawer Soccer and College Soccer News, respectively. Her sophomore campaign saw her pick up another 24 appearances and garner first-team All-American, Pac-12 Defender of the Year, and Most Outstanding Defensive Player at the College Cup as the Bruins won the national title. She continued to dominate as a junior by repeating as Pac-12 Defender of the Year and a first-team All-American, despite being upset by UC Irvine in the first round of the NCAA tournament. After training over the summer with Gotham FC and Angel City FC, her time in Westwood ended with another stellar season, compiling a total record of 71-9-7 and receiving Big Ten Defender of the Year, first-team All-Big Ten, and first-team All-American.

Beyond her performance at multiple positions, Reale's leadership helped the program achieve high levels of success. “Lilly only has one volume, which is loud,” said UCLA head coach Margueritte Aozasa. “She's kind of like a coach on the field. She's directing, she's encouraging, she's organizing things, and that's why I think our team really looks to her to be a leader for us... Lilly was just a player that, right away, you notice her potential.”

In January, Reale signed with Gotham on a three-year deal, receiving her debut in the season opener and starting the following week against Orlando Pride. She has made 21 total appearances across all competitions, scored her first goal in a 3-1 victory against the North Carolina Courage, and started as her side claimed the 2025 CONCACAF Champions Cup with a 1-0 win over Tigres. The league named her to the Best XI for the month of April, while the defender has met her stated objective of “adjusting to the speed of play” and “putting forth the most consistent performances.”

“I think it's definitely an adjustment as it always will be, going into the pros,” Reale told the Sports & SHEnanigans podcast. “Playing against and with a lot of my role models growing up – just players I've looked to for so long for little tips and tricks to add to my game – to now play against them in training every day is so much fun… [It's] awesome to pick their brain and understand who they are, not only as a player but also as a person. [That] has been probably the most exciting part for me… The back line that I'm fortunate to work with right now has been awesome.”

At the international level, Reale began appearing with the United States program for the Under-15 team in 2017 and was a member of the side that won the 2022 CONCACAF U-20 Championship before dumping out of the group stage at the ensuing U-20 World Cup. After being included in January's Futures Camp, she played with the Under-23 squad in June's two friendlies against Germany and scored in the opening fixture. Her first senior call-up came during the most recent camp, with her debut cap coming in the first 4-0 win over Ireland; during the 90-minute appearance, her tackle and assist set up Alyssa Thompson for the fourth goal. Hayes utilized her again for the full match in the 3-0 victory against rivals Canada, with Goal describing her as “looking as if she's been playing alongside [Naomi] Girma forever” and “great on the ball.”

Standing at five feet, nine inches tall, Reale is a defender who can deploy at left fullback and centre-back, racking up tackles and clearances every match and looking to beat opponents off the dribble by displaying “great attacking qualities” and accurate crosses. She is praised for being “fearless, physical, capable of contributing on both ends of the field, and [able] to elevate play,” seeking out the ball and “committing high to snuff out attacks early.” Her communication and assertion of control over proceedings have been noted despite her newness to the professional level.

“My tenacity [is my greatest on-field attribute],” said Reale. “Being a defender, you have to be really competitive and gritty. So, in moments where I have to track back or lay a tackle, I feel like I find that competitiveness and channel that. I like to say that I'm a pretty tenacious player… It's something that I definitely pride myself on and try to bring into my game every game that I play. Keeping that up and holding myself to that standard is a big thing.”

Reale finally made her way to the professional level after dominating the college scene and quickly became a key player for her club and entered the national team picture. She has the talent and potential to contribute to the USWNT, as Hayes appears to be intrigued by the rookie. There is a chance for her to seize her spot in the depth chart, with the all-important CONCACAF Championship taking place in November of 2026.

Title: Best of 2025 Panini Prizm FIFA Club World Cup
Description:
In this story:

Panini is hoping that soccer fans will be feeling nostalgic for summer when they finally release their 2025 Panini Prizm FIFA Club World Cup trading card product worldwide on September 12, 2025.

The international competition took place in the United States this summer and English Premier League side Chelsea FC were the victors after defeating Ligue 1's Paris Saint-Germain, the reigning UEFA Champions League winners, 3-0 on July 13 at Metlife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

Each hobby box of 2025 Panini Prizm FIFA Club World Cup has 12 packs in each box with each pack containing 12 cards. One case of includes 2025 Panini Prizm FIFA Club World Cup a dozen boxes. Each box contains (on average) one autograph, five numbered prizm parallels, eight additional prizms, two silver inserts and ten additional inserts within the 12-pack configuration.

RELATED: Best of 2024 Topps Finest MLS Cards

Here are the best from 2025 Panini Prizm FIFA Club World Cup:

Base #42 Cole Campbell - Borussia Dortmund

If you're looking for a long-term investment in a player's career, Cole Campbell is a very fun option from Panini's Club World Cup set. 

Campbell, who is eligible to represent the United States and Iceland on the international stage, is a fun talent to keep an eye on as he tries to find his way in Germany with Borussia Dortmund. Only 19 years old, Campbell is a great buy-low option in this set for a solid second-year card of a potential USMNT player down the line. 

Color Blast #17 Vini Jr. - Real Madrid

Vini Jr. is one of the best players on the planet and Color Blasts are among the most popular hits that collectors are seeking, making his Color Blast a must-have for serious collectors of this product. Vini Jr.'s career is still on the rise and is a safe bet to make a major impact on the pitch over the next 12 months for club and country.

RELATED: Lionel Messi is Dominating the 2025 Topps Now MLS checklist, is that a Good Thing?

Color Blast Duals #8 Erling Haaland and Kevin De Bruyne - Manchester City

Color Blast Duals are a fun item to chase, particularly for Manchester City supporters. Getting a card with both Erling Haaland and Kevin De Bruyne on it creates interest from multiple collector markets with two major European players, even if they are no longer teammates at Manchester City.

Kaboom! #3 Diego Maradona - Boca Juniors

It seems like the entire trading card world wants to have a Kaboom! hit in their collection regardless of the sport, so why wouldn't you want a Kaboom! of one of the greatest athletes of the 20th Century?

New Era Insert #10 Martinelli - Fluminense

The 2025 FIFA Club World Cup showcased the talent of South American clubs and Brazilian side Fluminense was at the forefront of that movement as they made it to semifinals before losing to eventual-champions Chelsea FC. Martinelli is a major player at the moment and everyone who cares about the FIFA Club World Cup needs to commemorate Fluminense's run properly. 

Prizmania Insert #2 Cole Palmer - Chelsea

Chelsea won the actual tournament so they needed to be included on this list and Cole Palmer secured their victory of Paris Saint-Germain in the final after scoring twice for his side before halftime as they cruised to a 3-0 win. Palmer has been a top player for Chelsea since arriving from Manchester City and every serious soccer collector needs him in their collection. 

Global Graphs Autograph #23 Lionel Messi - Inter Miami

Inter Miami was more or less gifted a spot into the 2025 FIFA Club World Cup and every soccer collector needs a Lionel Messi autograph, so why not commemorate the two with a Lionel Messi Inter Miami Global Graphs Autograph?

GUADALAJARA, Mexico – World Cup 2026 co-hosts Mexico, Canada and the United States are less than a year away from organizing what is expected to be a transformational tournament. Stateside industry talk has focused on the impact that a World Cup on home soil could have in further developing the sport in the world‘s most commercialized country.

Advertisement

But south of the border in Mexico, where fútbol is already the most popular sport and the domestic league is the most-viewed in the U.S., leading football officials view the World Cup as a runway that could lead to groundbreaking cross-border growth for Liga MX. Foreign investment has already become a factor and is poised to increase in stature, while commercial opportunities could turn Mexico's first division into one of the world's most profitable leagues and leave MLS, a valued partner, behind.

For starters, the door for foreign domestic leagues to play league matches in the U.S. may be swung wide open. Barcelona is hoping to play an official La Liga fixture against Villarreal in Miami this December. Serie A hopes to stage a December match between AC Milan and Como in Perth, Australia. Both remain on hold after a UEFA decision on Thursday to postpone a final ruling on the viability instead of making one as planned. Regardless, it's a concept that is tied to the ongoing globalization of the sport. In Europe, moving matches to the U.S. is not only highly controversial, it borders on blasphemy. That hurdle doesn't exist for North America's foremost league and footballing nation.

Mexico's men's national team plays regularly in the U.S., with crowds that dwarf those of the actual home team. Liga MX is already the domestic league king in its neighboring country. Now, Mexican football wants to take the next step. The novel Leagues Cup, a tournament that pits Mexico's 18 first-division clubs against 18 of the top MLS teams, is merely an appetizer to what could be a gluttonous proposal for Liga MX's top brands.

“We don't understand why a game from a European league is being prioritized when we're the neighbors, and you could call us MLS' partners, through various tournaments including Leagues Cup,” Club América president Santiago Baños told reporters recently. “Why prioritize the Spanish league and not us? If the game between Barcelona and Villarreal is allowed to be played, we will do anything possible to play an official Liga MX match in the United States.”

Advertisement

The most influential voices in Mexican football are not tip-toeing around this. If Liga MX is able to strengthen an already massive footprint in the U.S., that could be viewed as a threat to the development of MLS.

“The opportunity is so big that there are many ways to actually go for it,” Grupo Orlegi chairman Alejandro Irarragorri told The Athletic. “So we can go together (with MLS) or we can go in separate ways.”

Grupo Orlegi owns Club Santos Laguna and Atlas FC, in addition to second-division Spanish side Sporting Gijón. Atlas is up for sale as Orlegi seeks to distance itself from the Mexican tradition of multi-club ownership. Irarragorri, for his part, has long pushed for Liga MX to work closer with its American neighbors. The mutual interests that both leagues have sought to capitalize on outweigh the drawbacks of the partnership.

“I've been discussing this integration, at some point it was called a merger,” Irarragorri said. “I don't think a merger is necessary, but I've discussed it with many owners and particularly with some of my closest MLS owners. I remember saying that in the short term, (Leagues Cup) was maybe better for MLS. In the medium term, maybe it was better for Liga MX. But I truly believe that in the long term this is better for both leagues.”

MLS wants to appeal to the millions of Mexican-American fans in the U.S. and expose its clubs to more competitive matches against Liga MX teams. Club officials in Mexico, along with the Mexican Football Federation, view tournaments against MLS teams as commercially viable brand-building exercises. Leagues Cup, though, has not gained much traction since its launch in 2023.

The tournament is only played in U.S. stadiums, running from late July to late August, when Liga MX sides are at the start of their Apertura tournament. Leagues Cup in its current state doesn't benefit Liga MX – it clearly favors MLS teams.

Advertisement

Liga MX can continue to play friendlies in the U.S. in front of its loyal fanbase. But if the stakes are higher, Mexican football can potentially increase its market share on the other side of the border. Official matches in sold-out U.S. stadiums would put three points on the line in a league where narrow title races are common.

“Globalization used to be innovative. Now it's happening,” said Atlas FC president Aníbal Fájer. “Having this closeness to the States and having all of these fans there, it's something that we have to do.”

Fájer listed Major League Baseball, the NBA, NFL and Formula 1 as Liga MX's primary competitors, though; not MLS.

“They're all coming to play official matches in Mexico. They're building that market and it's growing. That's our competition,” Fájer said.

Added Irarragorri: “The fact of the matter is that we, as Liga MX, have a great market in the U.S. We have followers, we have our fans, we have people who are committed to our league, to our teams, to our history, to our heritage, to our sport. That won't change with Concacaf tournaments, with a Club World Cup or with the (2026) World Cup. That's a great powerhouse for the development of soccer in the U.S.”

Meanwhile, Liga MX president Mikel Arriola told The Athletic in August that a decision to play official Liga MX fixtures in the U.S. “would be made together with MLS.”

There's a championship spirit that runs through the $24 million Academia AGA in Guadalajara. The Atlas training facility, a six-acre venue, features a school, a small Catholic church, men's and women's dorms and the latest in sports science technology. Atlas is still buzzing from the team's back-to-back Liga MX championships in 2021 and 2022.

Those triumphs ended a 70-year title drought that had threatened the club's existence. After over a century of football, Atlas became a dying brand in Liga MX before Grupo Orlegi acquired it in 2019.

Advertisement

Sipping coffee in the open-air complex, Fájer, 35, raises his voice in order to cut through the noise of a heated U-21 match between Atlas and Club América on one of the facility's six pitches. “This is the heart of the club,” he said. “It's our safe place. It's our bunker.”

Later on this day, Fájer would speak in front of a group of the club's most important sponsors at Guadalajara's five-star Grand Fiesta Americana Country Club. “As you know, we've announced the sale of the club,” he said, as he sought to calm concerns. “But we remain focused on the day-to-day. That won't change.”

Fájer is in his 13th year at Orlegi. He has risen through the ranks, having served as its head of business intelligence and working within the organization's mergers and acquisitions division. In short, he knows what a takeover entails. He was heavily involved in the purchase and culture transformation of Atlas. But now, while he remains busy running Atlas, Irarragori is entertaining offers for the club.

“We're really responsibly looking for the best group to take Atlas to where it belongs,” he said. Grupo Orlegi's decision to sell Atlas has reached the highest office in the city.

“When I spoke with (Irarragorri) and was informed of Grupo Orlegi's decision to sell Atlas, I understood the situation,” Governor Pablo Lemus told The Athletic. “However, I raised only one condition: that the team does not leave Guadalajara, because it is truly very important for the people of our city. The only condition I told them was that the team must stay in Guadalajara.”

“Anyone who acquires the team,” Lemus continued, “will not find a fan base as loyal as Atlas's. They will not find the advantages that our city offers, nor a sports center like the one Atlas built, which is world-class.”

The imminent sale of a club with a loyal fanbase and a contemporary training facility could signal a new era for Mexican club football. There's growing interest from foreign investors during a time when private investment has become a trend in world football.

Advertisement

La Liga finalized a deal in 2021 with CVC Capital Partners for a reported $3.2 billion, for example. Clearlake Capital is the majority owner of Premier League side Chelsea, while private equity group Arctos Partners acquired a minority common equity stake in current European champion PSG in 2023.

Those are just a few examples of how global football has become more lucrative than ever. This year was supposed to mark the beginning of a league-wide investment deal between Liga MX, NFL owners and asset management leader Apollo. The deal was scrapped last December after Liga MX owners failed to vote on it, leading to the resignation of the league's former commissioner president, Juan Carlos Rodríguez.

At the time, it was a blow to Liga MX and a reminder that traditional boardroom diplomacy is not always the norm in Mexico. The Apollo deal was expected to not only significantly increase commercial spend in Liga MX, but also spearhead the centralization of the league's media rights. Chivas and Club América, for example, have benefited tremendously from having their own rights packages.

The alternative deal would include all 18 clubs, boosting Liga MX's value and its stronghold in the U.S.

“I think one great generator of information and indicators was the process that we had with Apollo,” Arriola said. “Apollo is now on hold, it didn't fall apart. We have the offer. We have the evaluation. And we have the interest. So what we have to do before that, is to generate a corporate governance reform in the league in order to see the conditions to centralize the TV rights and then decide if we want a 19th partner.”

With Apollo's original offer in limbo, and with the dotted line still blank, competing investment firms have begun to circle. This coincides with the growing interest of foreign ownership in Liga MX.

Advertisement

Atlético San Luis is co-owned by La Liga side Atlético Madrid. Necaxa is partially owned by NX Football USA, led by American businessman Sam Porter and celebrity investor Eva Longoria; Wrexham AFC co-owners Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney are involved, as well. U.S. based MountainStar Sports Group co-owns FC Juárez.

“I think that the future is becoming a reality today, because Necaxa was sold at two-times (revenue),” Arriola said. “Querétaro five times, to an owner in the U.S. And then we have in parallel an operation with Atlas.”

History was made earlier this year when Querétaro was acquired by Innovatio Capital, becoming the first Liga MX club with majority U.S. ownership. Innovatio Capital founder Marc Spiegel, who is based in Atlanta, first considered acquiring English Championship side Charlton Athletic and a handful of other European clubs.

“That experience really started to crystallize what our investment thesis is, because for us, buying a club that really had no chance to break even from a cash flow perspective wasn't interesting,” Spiegel told The Athletic. “But I'd be lying if I said that we were really focused on Mexico.”

A careful analysis of the North American market convinced Spiegel and his team of investors that Liga MX, and Mexico, were the right fit, after getting past what he described as the initial “allure of being in one of the big five European leagues.”

“(Querétaro) is booming and blossoming into a hub for international business,” Spiegel said. “(Liga MX) teams are profitable. There's a growing interest level. There are opportunities to even make this a borderless transaction between (Mexico and the U.S.). We felt like there wasn't anything that came close to this from a growth and upside perspective.”

“There's so much untapped right now, be it from commercial to media to fan engagement to collaboration with MLS to games in the United States,” he continued. “There's just not one. And looking at the fragmented nature of the media rights deal, it's the biggest league in the world that hasn't centralized. And you've seen the growth that happens with that.”

Advertisement

Spiegel said that Irarragorri was the first Liga MX owner to call him and congratulate him for acquiring Querétaro. The club nearly ceased to exist following a horrendous incident of stadium violence at Estadio La Corregidora in 2022.

The Mexican Football Federation's (FMF) Disciplinary Commission fined Querétaro and issued a one-year stadium ban at La Corregidora. The previous ownership group was banned from Mexican football for five years and the club was placed for sale. Spiegel and Innovatio Capital bought it in July for more than $120 million.

Elsewhere, Grupo Pachuca is reportedly considering selling Club León. The organization also owns CF Pachuca, but its multi-ownership structure led to the expulsion of León from the Club World Cup. That could potentially lead to another foreign-owned Liga MX club, something Spiegel described as “inevitable.”

“The process going on with Atlas, I'd say it's highly likely that it sells to an American or to an American group,” he said. “I think if we're sitting here having a conversation three years from now, I think you'll see two or three more (American-owned clubs). There are just so many parallels.”

“When you talk to people outside of Mexico about Liga MX,” Spiegel added, “You talk to people in Europe, they're like, ‘This is a sleeping giant.' People don't know what this could be. It could be huge. And I think understanding there is quality from a sporting perspective, but also being so tied naturally to the United States from a commercial standpoint.”

Spiegel sees a future where Liga MX and MLS move past their current state, which he called “dating” to a relationship that could change the sport forever. Leagues Cup, he said, is just the tip of the iceberg.

“Do the two leagues merge one day?” Spiegel asked. “I think that could be a game-changer globally in the football space. I think if that happens, you probably have the second biggest league in the world behind England. A lot of things have to happen, but I think that it makes a lot of sense.”

Advertisement

As both MLS and Liga MX consider their own growth strategies, the 2026 World Cup will provide the ideal sales and marketing pitch for both leagues. MLS has made significant strides over the past decade, and the most recent transfer window was a clear indicator of progress. Per MLS, clubs spent nearly $336 million in player acquisitions, a league record.

Despite that milestone, MLS continues to be held back by its distinct financial rules and restrictions. In Mexico, however, the gloves are coming off. With foreign capital now actively flowing through the league and a new media rights deal on the horizon, Liga MX is primed for its own foundational transformation.

Paul Tenorio contributed reporting to this story.

(Top photo: Azael Rodriguez/Getty Images)

Title: World Cup Millions Boost Al Ahly's Finances Amid On Field Woes
Description:
Manage your account



...

Club World Cup windfall and Adidas deal boost Egyptian champions' finances

World Cup Millions Boost Al Ahly's Finances Amid On Field Woes

Egyptian giants Al Ahly confirmed football surplus of EGP 45 million for the 2024 /25 financial year following strong revenues from international participation & commercial deals.

The club's board approved total budget of EGP 8.488 billion (176m dollar) for the year reflecting Al Ahly's growing economic strength.

Much of the surplus came from the team's appearance at the FIFA club World cup which generated close to USD 11m before tax deductions.

Al Ahly also confirmed the renewal of its long term kit partnership with Adidas running from 2026 to 2030. While financial details remain undisclosed, local media reported the deal to be worth USD 11m.

Despite the positive financial news, Al Ahly face challenges on the pitch. With just 1 win in 4 Egyptian Premier League match, the club parted ways with Spanish coach Jose Rivero.a

EPL

Liam Delap is yet to announce himself properly at Stamford Bridge and, for now, that is how things will stay.

That is not a criticism of Delap. The 22-year-old cannot be accused of dragging his heels: he made his Chelsea debut at the Club World Cup less than two weeks after joining from Ipswich Town, going on to play in six games at the tournament, score once and assist once, and collect his winner's medal.

Advertisement

But that was on the other side of the Atlantic, out of sight of the Stamford Bridge faithful. He has not yet made his new club his own.

He had little chance to do so in a cameo as a substitute against Crystal Palace on the opening weekend, and his next home appearance, against Fulham, lasted less than 15 minutes before he limped off with a hamstring injury. The Athletic reported on Tuesday that the England international does not need surgery, but Chelsea head coach Enzo Maresca told reporters on Friday that the centre-forward is expected to be out for 10-12 weeks, so has “a long way to go” in his rehabilitation.



The timing is cruel.

Delap has waited for his opportunity with a top club: he watched his former Manchester City academy team-mate Cole Palmer competing for European qualification while he was shouldering the goalscoring burden in an Ipswich team bound for relegation. After standing out with 12 Premier League goals last term, his first season in the top flight, he was courted by numerous Premier League teams and took on the mantle of starting centre-forward at one of the country's biggest clubs.

At Chelsea, Delap was hoping to spend the coming weeks learning the ropes of Champions League football. Instead, the most valuable lesson his new club can teach him is patience.

“He will be desperate, no doubt, to push that process and get back as soon as possible,” says former Watford, Reading, and Norwich City physiotherapist Luke Anthony. “But with a hamstring, if you get that wrong and (the player) re-injures, then you're looking at missing another two or three months.”



There are particular risks around Delap's potential for re-injury. As Anthony explains, young players who have not previously experienced a certain type of injury — such as a hamstring tear — might be lulled into a false sense of security that draws them back to action too soon. Delap has no recorded history of hamstring or soft-tissue problems, making this new territory.

Advertisement

“Once you're about three-quarters of the way through the process, you should feel good and feel like you're back to normal,” says Anthony. “But (young players) maybe don't have that experience to say: ‘Actually, I understand that I've got to get this last bit of work done, I've got to really cross the T's, dot the I's, before I get back into it'.

“That's where the staff around the process, medical staff, mostly the coaching staff, performance staff, and the manager, are key to making sure you manage that process dispassionately.

“Injuries are very emotional things. There's a lot at stake for different people. But if you just go on what the player tells you, then that's only a small part of the picture, and you could well get that wrong.”

Players increasingly understand that it is in their interest to prevent re-injury, Anthony says, with an increased focus on injury history in recruitment processes.

Delap will know the importance of patience — but that does not mean it will be easy to accept. “He has signed for a huge Premier League club, he's going to have a bunch of objectives,” says sports psychologist Dan Abrahams. “He wants to hit the ground running, get in the team, stay in the team, win games.

“Suddenly, because of his injury, all these dreams and goals have been hampered.

“This is where a multidisciplinary team is so important. This is where the sports psychologist gets involved with the medical team, because the team can help Delay see and understand the medical evidence, so that they can weave an effective story.

“What you're trying to do is help him think rationally about his situation. His brain and body want to send him impatient thoughts: ‘I have to get back and prove myself'. It's trying to help him use his self-talk to weave a story of intelligence, integrity, patience — one that is evidence-driven. ‘I am young, I've got a long career ahead, what I don't want to do is damage this further'.”

Former Liverpool physiotherapist Andy Renshaw says winning a player's trust in the rehabilitation process is key.

Advertisement

“You can do that by explaining it and giving them a little bit of education: 'There's our table of these injuries in the past, that's how long they've been'," he says. "Have you got anyone else — any of your friends or any other players that you know — who have been through this injury that you'd want to speak to? Just give them the benefit of experience from other people they might trust.”

To that end, the Chelsea forward could speak to his father, Rory, whose 19-year professional career took in spells at seven clubs. Delap Snr has plenty of experience with injuries striking at inopportune moments.

An ankle problem ruled him out of Southampton's appearance at the 2003 FA Cup final. On his home debut for Stoke City on loan in October 2006 — against parent club Sunderland — he broke his leg in two places, ruling him out for the rest of the season. His son is not facing anything like that length of layoff, but the two can empathise over the disappointment of an injury derailing their chance to hit the ground running.

After returning to Stoke in the 2007-08 season, Rory Delap went on to play for the club until 2013, helping them reach and stay in the Premier League.

The Chelsea forward has had his own setbacks to draw upon. He dealt with ankle ligament problems at Manchester City in the 2021-22 season and a knee injury while on loan at Hull in 2023-24. He then remained fit throughout his Premier League campaign with Ipswich.

“I've managed to focus and work hard and, importantly, not rush things,” he told The National in 2022 after suffering that ankle ligament issue at City. “I am still so young and had to make sure the injuries healed properly so there are no issues later in my career. Patience has obviously been key."

“Talent development pathways are becoming quite sophisticated,” adds Abrahams. “They know that roadblocks and speed bumps — challenging times put in the way of young players — are important. No doubt he's had tough moments where he's had to weave a narrative when it's been challenging to do so.”

Delap's situation is far from ideal, but he has the chance to use this setback to create a potent narrative of resilience.

(Top photo: Nigel French/Sportsphoto/Allstar via Getty Images)

Title: NYC's next mayor to oppose World Cup surge pricing
Description:
Palmeiras fans at the Metlife Stadium in New Jersey during the Club World Cup © Alamy

Posted on 12th September 2025

One of the leading candidates to be New York City's next mayor has started a petition against FIFA's plans to use surge or dynamic pricing at next year's World Cup.

Zohran Mamdani, currently leading the race to become the next mayor of New York City, has launched a “Game Over Greed” campaign that is calling on the global game's governing body to drop its plans to use dynamic pricing for next summer's World Cup.

Surge pricing models can lead to significant price increases depending on demand – and the FSA has previously spoken out against its use in football, with FSA chair Tom Greatrex speaking to MPs in Parliament in February 2025.

Senior FIFA sources have said, according to reports from The Athletic this week, that prices start at $60 for the cheapest group-stage seats and range up to $6,730 for the most expensive non-corporate tickets for the final.

Now Mamdani is calling for an end to its implementation at the World Cup along with a cap on ticket resales and 15% of match tickets set aside for local residents at a discounted rate.

“People across this, across this country, across the world are fed up with a model of ticket pricing that views fans as a commodity that can be priced higher and higher and higher.” https://t.co/uN0knBFsWJ

— Zohran Kwame Mamdani (@ZohranKMamdani) September 10, 2025



Mamdani's petition says: “The FIFA World Cup is coming to New York City next year. It's an incredible opportunity for economic growth and community spirit in our city — but only if working-class New Yorkers can actually attend the matches.

“This year, for the first time, FIFA is using dynamic pricing for ticket sales. They can raise prices, in real time, depending on how much profit they think they can make off us. Those tickets can then be resold on an official FIFA platform with NO price cap — yet another method of gatekeeping the game. And to make matters worse, unlike for the past three World Cups, there are no seats set aside for local residents.

“The biggest sporting event in the world is happening in our backyard and the vast majority of New Yorkers won't be able to see it.”

Last autumn the FSA submitted evidence to Parliamentary investigations into the use of surge pricing in the sporting and cultural sectors.

FSA Tom Greatrex said: “Dynamic pricing models are just the latest way in which some are determined to exploit the loyalty of football supporters, without any recognition of the downsides on atmosphere, occasion and attendance, that are an integral part of what makes elite football so marketable.

“It is only a couple of years since clubs and owners said football without fans is nothing – this approach risks pricing out the fans whose loyalty, passion and commitment is part of the ‘product' sold around the world.”

The World Cup is a generational opportunity for many fans and every effort should be made to keep it as accessible as possible so we welcome Mamdani's political intervention.

In the meantime our Free Lions Fans' Embassy team will continue their preparations for the tournament as they ready themselves to help supporters over the largest – and possibly most expensive – World Cup to date.

Thomas Concannon from our Free Lions Fans' Embassy team said: “Dynamic pricing is yet another major challenge for supporters who wish to attend the World Cup.

“Official participating nation allocations often don't satisfy demand, meaning many supporters find themselves leaning on the official FIFA sales, and dynamic pricing models could easily scupper any realistic chance people have of being able to afford to attend this tournament.

“The costs will already be through the roof, with this being such a widespread tournament in terms of travel, the biggest in history. Hotel prices in host cities are already way above and beyond standard pricing.

“Dynamic pricing might be standard practice at sporting events in the US, but it is certainly not a standard practice on the world stage, and this is supposed to be a tournament for the world.

“We fear the unique atmosphere that football produces worldwide will not make an appearance at this tournament at many games due to the supporters who would normally be there to create it being priced out by this latest money grab.”

[email protected]

From reducing ticket prices to increasing FA Cup final allocations – if we stand together, we can win together. Strength comes in numbers.

© 2025 The Football Supporters' Association | All rights reserved | Site by Solution Group

Title: FIFA World Cup pre-sale ticket process is underway. What to know about Visa presale draw
Description:
Looking to snag tickets to 2026's World Cup, where 48 nations' soccer teams will battle in stadiums around the U.S., Mexico and Canada?

FIFA, soccer's global governing body, said on its website that, due to expected high demand, tickets will be released in phases.

And Wednesday, Sept. 10, was the early-ticketing process's first day.

Title: World Cup tickets: How many are available? How can I get some?
Description:
To stream WFAA on your phone, you need the WFAA app.

Next up in 5

Example video title will go here for this video

Next up in 5

Example video title will go here for this video









DALLAS — More than 1.5 million people in 210 different countries signed up in the first 24 hours of the Visa Presale Draw, according to FIFA. 

FIFA officials said most of the applications came from the United States, Mexico and Canada, which makes sense given they will jointly host the 2026 World Cup next summer. The highest sign-ups after that included Argentina, Colombia, Brazil, England, Spain, Portugal and Germany.

“The large number of entries submitted is a testament to the huge amount of excitement sparked across the globe by the FIFA World Cup 26 and the extent to which it's set to become a watershed in football history,” said FIFA World Cup 26 Chief Operating Officer, Heimo Schirgi.

The Visa Presale Draw will continue to be open until Sept. 19, so that 1.5 million figure should continue to grow. FIFA says it will randomly select applicants and notify them starting Sept. 29, giving them a date and time slot to purchase tickets (subject to availability), with time slots starting from Oct. 1.

It's not clear how many applicants from the Presale Draw will be selected. Each successful applicant will be able to purchase up to four tickets per match for up to 10 matches, capping each applicant at 40 for the tournament.

FIFA is hosting two more ticket draws in late October and mid-December. Tickets will go on sale again closer to the tournament in 2026 “on a first-come, first-served basis,” according to FIFA. FIFA also said it will start an official resale platform.

With demand being seemingly this high, getting your hands on tickets might seem fleeting. While tickets for all 104 matches will be put on sale, receiving a timeslot does not guarantee tickets will be available.

Here's a breakdown at how many will be available for the entire tournament: 

Tickets available for the entire World Cup: ~7.01 million

Ticket prices for next year's World Cup will range initially from $60 for group-stage matches to $6,730 for the final, but could change as soccer's top event adopts dynamic pricing for the first time.

The prices are up from a range of $25 to $475 for the 1994 tournament in the United States and for the U.S. dollar equivalent $69 to $1,607 when ticket details were announced for the 2022 tournament in Qatar.

The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Title: FIFA Impose Two 3-0 Forfeits in World Cup Qualifying
Description:
Home> Football> Football News

Ryan Smart

FIFA have officially imposed two 3-0 forfeits in World Cup qualifying after a failed appeal.

Qualifying for the 2026 tournament, which takes place in the United States, Canada and Mexico, is at different stages across the six continents.

Various controversies have taken place, particularly in the African and Asian sections.

Advert

In Asia, Pakistan were briefly suspended by FIFA for governmental interference, while Congo were banned for a similar reason in African qualifying.

The latter's first round group also included Eritrea, who pulled out before qualifying even began due to reported government concerns that players would attempt to flee in exile during away matches.

In Group H, meanwhile, Equatorial Guinea were among the favourites to progress from a group that also featured Liberia, Tunisia, Namibia, Malawi and Sao Tome and Principe.

They recorded crucial 1-0 wins over both Namibia and Liberia in November 2023, which would have seen them qualify for the second round as group runners-up.

But six months on, FIFA awarded a pair of 3-0 forfeit wins to their opponents, citing an ineligible player that had appeared in both matches.

That player was former Middlesbrough and Birmingham forward Emilio Nsue, who scored the winning goal in both games.

Advert

He was given a six-month ban from international football by FIFA.

What was unusual about the case is that Nsue, rather than having made his international debut in those two fixtures, is actually Equatorial Guinea's all-time top scorer, with 22 goals.

The row stemmed from the fact that the Mallorca-born forward had played for Spain's various junior sides at youth level.

His final match for Spain's U21 side was in 2011, with FIFA concluding in 2013 that he had not been formerly cleared to play for Equatorial Guinea after he was deemed ineligible to play in two 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Advert

The African nation's governing body, Feguifut, lodged a second eligibility request for Nsue earlier this year, which FIFA accepted in March.

Feguifut successfully proved that any person born to a mother or father from the country is automatically an Equatoguinean, with Nsue cleared to play.

Subsequently, an appeal was lodged to win back the six points that Equatorial Guinea had been forced to forfeit earlier in the qualifying campaign.

Advert

However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) have now formally rejected the appeal, due to the governing body not including the Namibian FA and Liberian FA in its appeal.

As a result, the two 3-0 forfeits imposed by FIFA remain in the record books.

Had Equatorial Guinea been successful, Namibia would have dropped out of the second round of qualifying.

CAS' verdict, which was delivered on July 28 but was only made public on Thursday, as per BBC Sport, reads: "Since the appeal is directed solely at FIFA and does not name the NFA and LFA as co-respondents, the panel concludes that the appeal must be dismissed."

Advert

FIFA had argued that their punishment was 'lenient' on the African nation as they could have excluded them from World Cup qualifying due to the seriousness of the breaches.

Topics: FIFA, FIFA World Cup

Title: Guns N'Roses Moves Concert Venue for El Salvador's World Cup Qualifiers
Description:
POPULAR SEARCHES
          


            BROWSE BY
          

Don't you cry, El Salvador fans. Thanks to Guns N'Roses, the men's national team will now have its fun and (very crucial) games at the country's main stadium. 

El Salvador will now play its two World Cup qualifying matches in October at Estadio Cuscatlán after the band agreed to move its forthcoming concert to another venue. 

Concert organizers confirmed that the band's October 4 concert will now be at Estadio Nacional Jorge "El Mágico" González to accommodate the games.

The Cuscatlán, El Salvador's largest stadium, is set to host La Selecta's qualifiers against Panama on October 10 and Guatemala on October 14. Officials had cautioned that holding a major concert days before those games would damage the pitch.

El Salvador is vying to reach its first World Cup since 1982 and is in the middle of a qualifying campaign through CONCACAF. The winner of its regional group will directly qualify for the expanded 48-team tournament. 

[WORLD CUP 2026: WHO CAN QUALIFY?]

Yamil Bukele, president of El Salvador's Instituto Nacional de los Deportes (INDES), thanked the band and promoters for their cooperation.

"We appreciate the willingness of Guns N' Roses and the organizing team to make this change so that fans of both soccer and music can enjoy world-class events," Bukele said in a statement.

Title: FIFA sees 1.5 million ticket applications for 2026 World Cup in 24 hours
Description:
More than 1.5 million ticket applications from fans in 210 countries have been received by FIFA within 24 hours of the presale draw for the 2026 World Cup being launched, according to REUTERS. The demand for the tournament “came primarily” from the U.S., Mexico and Canada, followed by Argentina, Colombia, Brazil, England, Spain, Portugal and Germany. Tickets will start at $60, yet dynamic pricing will be in operation during the first phase of ticket sales with fans “paying different prices according to market demand.” Additional ticket sales phases are scheduled to begin in October (REUTERS, 9/11). The CP's Neil Davidson noted the presale, which runs until Sept. 19, is a lottery open to Visa cardholders -- Visa is a FIFA partner -- and the first of several ticket windows ahead of the tournament. The initial bumper numbers come “despite some technical glitches” on the first day of the draw Wednesday, with some applicants facing lengthy waits after getting error messages or being kicked back to where they started from. The pre-sale draw will “involve approximately one million tickets” (CP, 9/11).

FREE ACCESS: REUTERS noted box and suite holders at Mexico City's Azteca stadium, also known as Estadio Banorte, will have “free access to 2026 World Cup matches” after they reached an agreement with FIFA. Under the terms of the long-standing contractual rights, box seat holders -- whose 99-year clause was originally established to help fund the stadium's construction in 1966 -- will be “granted free access to all five matches, including the tournament opener.” The stadium, which will have 90,000 seats after renovations, includes 12,500 individual box spaces. Box and suite holders will “need to register via a dedicated website,” with further details to be announced (REUTERS, 9/11).

Title: Now or never for Gabriel Martinelli: Enigmatic Arsenal winger facing fight to save Gunners career following Eberechi Eze and Noni Madueke arrivals
Description:
The Brazil international has yet to unlock his full potential at the Emirates Stadium, and could soon find himself on the fringes of the line up

Just over two years ago, Arsenal welcomed Nottingham Forest to the Emirates Stadium for their first Premier League game of the 2023-24 campaign. After a cagey first 25 minutes, Gabriel Martinelli conjured up the moment of magic his team were crying out for. There didn't look to be much on when the Brazilian picked the ball up on the left flank with two defenders closely tracking him, but he dribbled towards the byline before deceiving them both with an outrageous pirouette backheel pass to Eddie Nketiah, who subsequently shimmied inside and fired low into the net to give the Gunners the lead - with the aid of a slight deflection.

It was an instant assist-of-the-season contender that set Arsenal on their way to a 2-1 victory, a sublime piece of skill that very few players would even dare attempt, but Martinelli has always had that in his locker. The problem is, he hasn't pulled it out consistently enough.

Arsenal are preparing to host Forest again on Saturday, six years on from Martinelli's stunning introduction to English audiences, and he has yet to unlock his full potential. The enigmatic 24-year-old still has the capacity to be a match-winner, but more often than not, he frustrates with his decision-making and execution.

Time is now running out for him to change that. The summer arrivals of Eberechi Eze and Noni Madueke in north London have significantly increased competition in attack, while Leandro Trossard has agreed terms on a new contract, and Martinelli's position will come under serious threat if he continues to fall short with his end product. The former Ituano wonderkid has played a key role in Mikel Arteta's revolution to this point, but Arsenal need a lot more from him if they are to take the next step and get their hands on some major silverware.

Title: From world No. 1 to sneaker icon: Stan Smith documentary now streaming
Description:
Fans in New York joined the man himself for a special screening of “Who Is Stan Smith?” and a sneaker signing during the US Open.ByBaseline StaffPublished Sep 11, 2025 copy_link

Published Sep 11, 2025

© Weston Kloefkorn for NowThis/PC Richard & Son

Missing tennis after the non-stop action of the US Open?Don't worry, there's plenty more on tap. Davis Cup is already underway, followed by Laver Cup next week in San Francisco—both streaming on Tennis Channel. And if you're craving a mix of tennis and fashion history, you can now stream Who Is Stan Smith? on Hulu and ESPN+.After a limited theatrical run in 2024, the documentary takes a closer look at American tennis champion and sneaker icon Stan Smith. If you've ever laced up a pair of crisp white sneakers and wondered, “Who is Stan Smith?”—this one's for you.👉 Read More: The year of Tenniscore: How the 'Challengers' effect has transformed tennis fashion

If you've ever laced up a pair of crisp white sneakers and wondered, “Who is Stan Smith?”—this one's for you.© Weston Kloefkorn for NowThis/PC Richard & Son

© Weston Kloefkorn for NowThis/PC Richard & Son

Smith, a former world No. 1 and seven-time major champion, went from being one of the game's biggest stars to the face of Adidas when the brand launched the Stan Smith shoe in 1973. With his portrait and signature stamped on the white leather, the sneakers became Adidas' all-time best seller and a pop culture staple across hip hop, celebrity fashion, and today's tenniscore trend.But Stan Smith is more than just a shoe. The film highlights his work as a civil rights and AIDS activist, as well as his lasting impact on the sport as president of the International Tennis Hall of Fame since 2011.To mark the streaming release, Smith, 78, hosted a family-friendly book and sneaker signing at P.C. Richard & Son on the Upper West Side, followed by a special screening at the Seaport Racquet Club—an immersive pop-up created with Racquet Magazine—during the US Open. The event featured a panel with Smith, director Danny Lee, and author Mark Mathabane, whom Smith famously helped escape apartheid South Africa with a tennis scholarship in 1978.

Asked how many pairs he owns, Smith laughed:“It's a question everybody asks, and I don't know the answer," he told Forbes. "I think I own anywhere between 120 to 150 pairs of sneakers. I've got friends, though, that have anywhere from 300 to 450 shoes; some people are shoe collectors.”Produced by UNINTERRUPTED and Fulwell Entertainment, and presented by P.C. Richard & Son and Disney Advertising, the film offers an intimate portrait of the Hall of Famer whose influence spans sports, fashion, and activism. It features interviews with Smith, his family, and voices including John McEnroe, Darryl “DMC” McDaniels, Cari Champion, Bob Lutz, Jerry Lorenzo, Charlie Pasarell, Pharrell Williams, and more.

Title: Hamilton reckons Cadillac have picked 'the right guys'
Description:

F1 Drivers Vote For The Best Bromance | The 2025 F1 Yearbook

Getting to know... Franco Colapinto 

Lewis Hamilton has given his take on Cadillac's driver line-up for 2026, with his former team mate Valtteri Bottas set to partner Sergio Perez.

Lewis Hamilton believes that Cadillac have “chosen the right guys” after selecting Valtteri Bottas and Sergio Perez as their drivers for 2026, with the seven-time World Champion admitting that he still misses working with former team mate Bottas.

Just prior to the second half of the campaign getting underway, it was confirmed that Cadillac will run the veteran pair as their line-up for the team's maiden season next year, meaning that both drivers are making a comeback to the grid after spending 2025 on the sidelines.

The news was met with positive reactions from several drivers – including Perez's former Red Bull team mate Max Verstappen – and Hamilton has also welcomed the return of Bottas, who he raced alongside at Mercedes between 2017 and 2021.

When asked what sort of a driver Cadillac are getting, Hamilton responded: “I don't need to say anything about his talent because he's shown that throughout his career.

“But [they're] getting one of the most honest, probably the funniest, Finns I would imagine, and just the most genuine person to work with. I miss working with him.

“I think they've chosen the right guys. Obviously, we'll see with Sergio as well, he's got great experience. That knowledge that they both bring from two great teams will help them progress faster.”

Bottas and Perez indeed bring with them a wealth of experience, sharing a total of 527 Grand Prix starts and 16 Grand Prix wins between them.

Pushed on whether he feels it is a good decision to have two experienced names back in the sport, Hamilton reflected: “I think so. I think we have a good mix on the grid.

“I think it's amazing to have an extra team, and I think for a team to be able to develop, you have to have drivers who have experience, especially when it's a brand new team.

“You've got two different flavours coming from Red Bull and Mercedes with different knowledge and experience that they'll both be able to put into the pot and help the team move forward faster.”

Title: Cadillac boss Towriss explains Herta's bold move to F2
Description:
Authentics

Tickets

Hospitality

Previous

Next

F1 Drivers Vote For The Best Bromance | The 2025 F1 Yearbook

Getting to know... Franco Colapinto 

IndyCar driver Colton Herta is planning a move to Europe and Formula 2 in 2026, but will it result in a future Cadillac Formula 1 seat?

Cadillac Formula 1 Team CEO Dan Towriss has admitted that the squad's new test driver, Colton Herta, will be taking a “huge risk” with his planned switch from IndyCar to Formula 2 next year, but feels the American has the ingredients to succeed.

Herta, whose Cadillac testing role was announced earlier this month, is an established racer in the United States-based IndyCar Series, having made 116 starts and scored nine victories, 19 podium finishes and 16 pole positions so far.

While Valtteri Bottas and Sergio Perez will drive for Cadillac in their debut 2026 season and beyond, Herta is aiming to make a case for a future seat – and score valuable points towards a Super Licence – by swapping America for Europe and tackling the F2 feeder series directly below F1.

At the Italian Grand Prix, where Cadillac's chiefs made another visit to the paddock, Towriss explained the reasons behind Herta's upcoming move and noted how racing on the same tracks as F1 – as well as using tyres supplied by Pirelli – are key factors.

“For Colton, this has always been a dream of his, to drive in F1, but to do that, this is the path he had to take,” Towriss told Sky Sports F1. “He has to take a huge risk, a huge amount of risk – no seat is guaranteed. This is F1, so he wants to learn tracks and tyres and show that respect to European open-wheel racing.

“The entitlement model from the US hasn't worked out that well in the past, so we really want to build that body of work, the knowledge that's necessary, to see if he has what it takes to drive in Formula 1.”

Herta has already tested F1 machinery with McLaren and been in a simulator with several teams – Towriss keen to point out that, while results in IndyCar have been mixed, the 25-year-old “excelled” at every opportunity.

“He really is a special talent,” added Towriss. “I think a lot of people look at some of the results in IndyCar and say, ‘Well, he hasn't won a championship, he's not with [multiple champion] Alex Palou'.

“I think as a team owner I would take some responsibility for that; there have been times where there have been troubles on pit lane or strategy didn't work out, but Colton's an immense talent and he really can find speed where others can't.

“I think any time he's had a chance to do a test, whether it was with McLaren, or time that he's been in the sim with Alpine, Red Bull and Sauber, from that standpoint he really has excelled and shown really high potential and promise for an F1 seat.

“Now this is the chance to do it. He's had to choose this path of taking a big risk to not have that guarantee of the seat. He's leaving behind what at this point is very comfortable for him, to choose something that's uncomfortable for him – but no risk, no reward, as they say.”

When he heads to F2, it will not be the first time that Herta has raced in Europe – the California native previously competing on the continent from 2015-16 and spending time as Lando Norris' team mate in the MSA Formula Championship.

Title: How Daniel Ricciardo defined his own style
Description:
Authentics

Store

Tickets

Hospitality

Experiences

Previous

Next

Upcoming

F1 Drivers Vote For The Best Bromance | The 2025 F1 Yearbook

Getting to know... Franco Colapinto 

From his Formula 1 debut in Toro Rosso, all the way to announcing his retirement from racing in 2025, here's how F1's very own Honey Badger defined his paddock style throughout his racing career

Daniel Ricciardo has always been one of Formula 1's most magnetic personalities. His career wasn't just about race wins, shoey podiums, and daring overtakes. It was about the joy he carried with him everywhere, the humour he shared in interviews, and the way he made everyone around him feel like part of the show.

That infectious personality extended to his wardrobe. Ricciardo never set out to be a fashion icon, but over time he built a personal style that felt unmistakably his own. It wasn't about trends or approval; it was about wearing what made him happy.

When he first arrived on the grid in 2011 with HRT, his look was what you would expect from a rookie – team kit, hoodies, caps, and sneakers. But even then, his personality occasionally peeked through in brightly coloured trainers or playful hats.

Much like his early driving, there was a spark that hinted at bigger things to come. Fans were quick to notice his charm and cheek, and the nickname “Honey Badger” started circulating, perfectly capturing the blend of fearless aggression and cheeky humour that defined him.

As his career progressed, so did his confidence both on and off the track. By 2014, as a three-time race winner with Red Bull, Ricciardo's style had started to evolve into something more playful. Oversized tees, patterned button-ups, tinted aviators, and his ever-present black Vans shoes became staples. He wasn't dressing to impress anyone but himself, and that authenticity made him stand out in a paddock that could otherwise feel uniform.

1 / 5

His personality extended beyond the racetrack. Fans loved his radio callouts – from funny quips to his spontaneous humour during races – which became just as famous as his overtakes. There were moments like the chaotic 2016 Monaco Grand Prix where his laughter over the radio made headlines, and, of course, the shoeys. Each podium celebration was a joyous statement that sometimes ended in champagne all over the team, and usually over himself too.

He also had a knack for leaning into the culture of wherever the F1 circus landed. Speaking to GQ Australia, Ricciardo said that travel shaped his style more than anything. “The more I travel, the more I recognise I am drawn to the styles of each place. I guess you could say I dress to the setting and go with the flow.”

Nowhere was this more obvious than in Austin, where he embraced his “honorary Texan” status with cowboy boots, Stetson hats, and even arriving at the paddock on horseback in 2022. Other weekends brought different twists, from Western belt buckles to Mexico-inspired sombreros, but, for Daniel, it was always about having fun.

1 / 8

This light-hearted spirit eventually found its way into fashion more deliberately with the birth of his lifestyle label. Ricciardo's first foray came via his RIC3 merchandise, which included 'Enchanté' – a small line of hoodies and tees that felt closer to his own wardrobe than traditional F1 fanwear.

Fans responded immediately – the pieces were wearable, authentic, and reflected Ricciardo's own approach to clothes and style. By January 2023, the line had grown into a separate lifestyle brand, Enchanté, boasting an array of oversized tees, playful graphics, and bold colours.

“It started as a bit of a laugh,” he told GQ Australia, recalling a friend in Monaco who would say “enchanté” instead of cheers. What began as a joke became the perfect encapsulation of Ricciardo's aesthetic.

Enchanté wasn't just for fans. Fellow drivers were often seen sporting the pieces around the paddock or at casual team events. Ricciardo wore the brand himself because it felt right, not for promotion.

“When I'm not in a cowboy get-up or a homespun Bode shirt, I'll be in a hoodie or T-shirt of my own making,” he said to GQ, showing how the brand was as much a reflection of his personal style as it was fanwear.

1 / 8

In his later F1 seasons at McLaren, as Red Bull's reserve driver, and finally during his stint with Racing Bulls, Ricciardo doubled down on comfort and individuality. Oversized tees, slouchy cardigans and easy layering became his signature, with plenty of Enchanté pieces mixed in. Still, he showed he could switch gears when the moment called for it.

At the 2023 Met Gala, his first time at the biggest night in fashion, Ricciardo traded in his hoodies and Vans for a custom suit in black grosgrain ribbon tweed, complete with a sharp waistcoat and jacket. He even slipped a hip flask into his look, which was a typically cheeky touch from the Honey Badger.

Vogue even covered his getting-ready process for the event, a high compliment that highlighted how effortlessly he could step into black-tie while still keeping his bubbly personality front and centre.

By the end of 2024, Ricciardo had stepped away from the grid, and his wardrobe made the transition seamlessly into his post-racing life. Instagram posts throughout 2025 show him at ease: walking along the beach, enjoying coffee runs ay home, and hanging out with those close to him.

Oversized hoodies, relaxed shorts, and his favourite tees (often Enchanté) still dominate the Aussie's wardrobe, and his clothing choices still reflect the same philosophy he's held for years: wear what makes you happy.

When he officially announced his retirement in September 2025, alongside his new role as Ford Racing ambassador, Ricciardo had already settled into a life with fewer schedules and more freedom. “The greatest thing about my days now is not having a schedule,” he reflected with GQ. After years of precise, high-pressure routines, he was enjoying the little things.

And yet, his signature playfulness remains. Speaking to GQ about his long-standing love of baggy tees, he said: “I have been wearing baggy tees for a long time. Maybe I will move from an XL to a M in some scenarios, for a cleaner look. I will be 36 this year, so I might experiment with 36-year-old clothing!”

Ultimately, Ricciardo's story is less about trends or accolades and more about authenticity. He dresses for himself, with a grin that could light up any paddock, a sense of humour, and the same joyous energy that has made him one of Formula 1's most beloved figures from day one. And yes, that cheesy grin is still very much part of the package wherever he goes.

1 / 9

Next Up

© 2003-2025 Formula One World Championship Limited

Mark Hughes and Giorgio Piola analyse why conditions were ideal at the 2025 Italian Grand Prix for Max Verstappen to drive “a race of perfection”.

Although Max Verstappen's victory at Monza on Sunday was his third of the season (not including the Spa Sprint event), it was the first time that the RB21 showed a genuine race day pace advantage over McLaren.

We've already seen other tracks at which the Red Bull's good aerodynamic efficiency when running low wing levels, notably Jeddah and Silverstone, has made it competitive. Monza, being a more extreme low-downforce track, was even better-suited to those car traits.

Title: F1 ACADEMY announces landmark rookie test to drive forward series' future talent
Description:
Authentics
